CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: 11 The mobility of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) was measured by using a field - effect transistor ( FET ) with a bottom-gate , top - contact device configuration built on an n - doped silicon wafer. Figure 5 shows the typical output and transfer curves of a representative device with PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) as the channel semiconductor. The hole mobility was estimated to be 0.05 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , which is 1-2 orders of magnitude higher than that of other effective D-A type low - bandgap photovoltaic polymers ( 2.6 x 10^-4 -3 x 10^-3 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ). 5 Although the FET mobility might not be directly correlated to the photovoltaic performance since the situation of the charge transport is quite different from each other , the higher carrier mobility still suggests effective charge carrier transport to the electrodes in the photovoltaic devices. Photovoltaic Properties. The bulk heterojunction PSCs were fabricated with the device structure of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) : PCBM ( or PC 70 BM ) / LiF / Al. PEDOT : PSS was spin - coated on a precleaned ITO - coated glass substrate. The film was dried at 150 °C under a N 2 atmosphere for 5 min. After cooling the substrate , a solution of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PCBM ( or PC 70 BM ) mixture ( 1 : 2 w / w ) was spin - coated , where a blend of chloroform and o-dichlorobenzene ( 4 : 1 v / v ) was used as the solvent. The devices were completed by evaporating LiF / Al as the cathode. The effective area ( 2 mm x 3 mm ) of the PSCs was defined using a metal photomask during irradiation with simulated solar light ( Scheme 2 ). PC 70 BM was also used as an acceptor because it has similar electronic properties as PCBM , but a higher absorption coefficient in the visible region , which can compensate for the poor absorption of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) in this range. Figure 6 shows the I-V curves of the devices with the best photovoltaic performance under the illumination of AM 1.5 ( 100 mW / cm^2 ). The corresponding open - circuit voltage ( V OC ) , short - circuit current ( I SC ) , fill factor ( FF ) , and PCE of the devices are also summarized in Figure 3. The external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) of the devices under the illumination of monochromatic light is shown in Figure 3. Compared with the PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) : PCBM system , the PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) : PC 70 BM system has higher EQE values of 30-40 % in the range of 450-850 nm , which contributes to the improvement of I SC from 11.31 to 14.87 mA / cm^2. Since the spectral response extends to over 1.1 μm , the spectral mismatch between the simulated and actual AM1.5 spectra must be considered.

Let's think step by step.

| Material Name |
|--------------|
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) |
| n-doped silicon wafer |
| ITO |
| PEDOT : PSS |
| LiF |
| Al |
| PCBM (or PC 70 BM) |
| chloroform |
| o-dichlorobenzene |

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
|--------------|
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) |
| n-doped silicon wafer |
| ITO |
| PEDOT : PSS |
| LiF |
| Al |
| PCBM (or PC 70 BM) |

These are the material names mentioned in the paragraph. The other entities mentioned, such as "FET," "bottom-gate," "top-contact," "device configuration," "solvent," "v/v," "w/w," and "N2 atmosphere," do not refer to specific materials.

Paragraph: 11 The mobility of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) was measured by using a field - effect transistor ( FET ) with a bottom-gate , top - contact device configuration built on an n - doped silicon wafer. Figure 5 shows the typical output and transfer curves of a representative device with PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) as the channel semiconductor. The hole mobility was estimated to be 0.05 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , which is 1-2 orders of magnitude higher than that of other effective D-A type low - bandgap photovoltaic polymers ( 2.6 x 10^-4 -3 x 10^-3 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 ). 5 Although the FET mobility might not be directly correlated to the photovoltaic performance since the situation of the charge transport is quite different from each other , the higher carrier mobility still suggests effective charge carrier transport to the electrodes in the photovoltaic devices. Photovoltaic Properties. The bulk heterojunction PSCs were fabricated with the device structure of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) : PCBM ( or PC 70 BM ) / LiF / Al. PEDOT : PSS was spin - coated on a precleaned ITO - coated glass substrate. The film was dried at 150 °C under a N 2 atmosphere for 5 min. After cooling the substrate , a solution of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PCBM ( or PC 70 BM ) mixture ( 1 : 2 w / w ) was spin - coated , where a blend of chloroform and o-dichlorobenzene ( 4 : 1 v / v ) was used as the solvent. The devices were completed by evaporating LiF / Al as the cathode. The effective area ( 2 mm x 3 mm ) of the PSCs was defined using a metal photomask during irradiation with simulated solar light ( Scheme 2 ). PC 70 BM was also used as an acceptor because it has similar electronic properties as PCBM , but a higher absorption coefficient in the visible region , which can compensate for the poor absorption of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) in this range. Figure 6 shows the I-V curves of the devices with the best photovoltaic performance under the illumination of AM 1.5 ( 100 mW / cm^2 ). The external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) of the devices under the illumination of monochromatic light is shown in Figure 3. Compared with the PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) : PCBM system , the PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) : PC 70 BM system has higher EQE values of 30-40 % in the range of 450-850 nm , which contributes to the improvement of I SC from 11.31 to 14.87 mA / cm^2. Since the spectral response extends to over 1.1 μm , the spectral mismatch between the simulated and actual AM1.5 spectra must be considered.

Let's think step by step.

1. FET mobility
2. PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) hole mobility
3. Carrier mobility
4. Effective area of PSCs
5. Voc (Open-circuit voltage)
6. Isc (Short-circuit current)
7. FF (Fill factor)
8. PCE (Power conversion efficiency)

10. PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) and PCBM (or PC 70 BM) ratio (1 : 2 w / w)

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Property name of material" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| FET mobility (of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu)) |
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) hole mobility |
| Effective area of PSCs |
| Open-circuit voltage (Voc) |
| Short-circuit current (Isc) |
| Fill factor (FF) |
| Power conversion efficiency (PCE) |
| External quantum efficiency (EQE) |
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) and PCBM (or PC 70 BM) ratio (1 : 2 w / w) |
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) hole mobility (1-2 orders of magnitude) |
| PC 70 BM absorption coefficient |

| Property Name | Description |
| --- | --- |
| FET mobility (of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu)) | The mobility of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) in a field-effect transistor (FET) |
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) hole mobility | The mobility of hole carriers in PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) |
| Effective area of PSCs | The active area of the bulk heterojunction perovskite solar cells (PSCs) |
| Open-circuit voltage (Voc) | The voltage at which the photovoltaic device generates no current |
| Short-circuit current (Isc) | The current generated by a photovoltaic device under short-circuit conditions |
| Fill factor (FF) | The ratio of the maximum reversible power output of a photovoltaic device to the product of its open-circuit voltage and short-circuit current |
| Power conversion efficiency (PCE) | The ratio of the electrical power output of a photovoltaic device to the incident solar power |
| External quantum efficiency (EQE) | The ratio of the number of electrons collected as current to the number of photons absorbed by the solar cell |
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) and PCBM (or PC 70 BM) ratio (1 : 2 w / w) | The weight ratio of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) to PCBM (or PC 70 BM) in the PSCs |
| PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) hole mobility (1-2 orders of magnitude) | The hole mobility of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) is 1-2 orders of magnitude higher than that of other effective D-A type low-bandgap photovoltaic polymers |
| PC 70 BM absorption coefficient | The absorption coefficient of PC 70 BM in the visible region |

Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: 11 The mobility of PDTP-DTDPP-(Bu) was measured by using a field - effect transistor ( FET ) with a bottom-gate , top - contact device configuration built on an n - doped silicon wafer. Figure 5 shows the typical output and transfer curves of a representative device with PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) as the channel semiconductor. Photovoltaic Properties. The bulk heterojunction PSCs were fabricated with the device structure of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) : PCBM ( or PC 70 BM ) / LiF / Al. PEDOT : PSS was spin - coated on a precleaned ITO - coated glass substrate. The film was dried at 150 °C under a N 2 atmosphere for 5 min. After cooling the substrate , a solution of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PCBM ( or PC 70 BM ) mixture ( 1 : 2 w / w ) was spin - coated , where a blend of chloroform and o-dichlorobenzene ( 4 : 1 v / v ) was used as the solvent. The devices were completed by evaporating LiF / Al as the cathode. The effective area ( 2 mm x 3 mm ) of the PSCs was defined using a metal photomask during irradiation with simulated solar light ( Scheme 2 ). PC 70 BM was also used as an acceptor because it has similar electronic properties as PCBM , but a higher absorption coefficient in the visible region , which can compensate for the poor absorption of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) in this range. Figure 6 shows the I-V curves of the devices with the best photovoltaic performance under the illumination of AM 1.5 ( 100 mW / cm^2 ). The corresponding open - circuit voltage ( V OC ) , short - circuit current ( I SC ) , fill factor ( FF ) , and PCE of the devices are also summarized in Figure 3. The external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) of the devices under the illumination of monochromatic light is shown in Figure 3. Compared with the PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) : PCBM system , the PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) : PC 70 BM system has higher EQE values of 30-40 % in the range of 450-850 nm , which contributes to the improvement of I SC from 11.31 to 14.87 mA / cm^2. Since the spectral response extends to over 1.1 μm , the spectral mismatch between the simulated and actual AM1.5 spectra must be considered.

Let's think step by step.

1. FET mobility: 0.05 cm^2 / V s^-1
2. Hole mobility of other effective D-A type low-bandgap photovoltaic polymers: 2.6 x 10^-4 - 3 x 10^-3 cm^2 / V s^-1
3. Temperature during PEDOT:PSS film drying: 150 °C
4. Time for PEDOT:PSS film drying: 5 min
5. Effective area of PSCs: 2 mm x 3 mm
6. Open-circuit voltage (Voc) of the devices: Values not provided in the paragraph
7. Short-circuit current (Isc) of the devices: 11.31 mA / cm^2 (for PDTP-DTDPP(Bu):PCBM system), 14.87 mA / cm^2 (for PDTP-DTDPP(Bu):PC 70 BM system)
8. Fill factor (FF) of the devices: Values not provided in the paragraph
9. Power conversion efficiency (PCE) of the devices: Values not provided in the paragraph
10. External quantum efficiency (EQE) of the devices under monochromatic light: Values ranging from 30-40% in the range of 450-850 nm
11. Absorption coefficient of PC 70 BM in the visible region: Higher than that of PCBM
